title: Am I my consciousness or do I have a consciousness? - Quora

response.answer_text: You have self-consciousness or self-conscious awareness which means you are conscious and know it. Self-consciousness is the knowledge the mind has of its act as its own.Self- consciousness demands a spiritual principle. A person is composed of a body and soul. Matter, and particularly the brain, cannot turn back on itself or reflect. The body and soul are unified into a single unified organism.Just for a few moments consider the fact that you are thinking. That you have thoughts. Either you think your own thoughts or the brain thinks for you. The notion is not only absurd but repugnant. It's repulsive.The brain can generate many things such as singular images, has sense memory and other operations but it cannot form concepts, form judgements, understand, reason. All of these operations transcend sense. They are suprasensuous. If you do not want to hold to the soul as the source of self-consciousness then you still cannot hold to matter as its source. This is why neuroscience will never find self-consciousness in the brain. It is a waste of time and money and research.

Neither of the two actually. Neither do “YOU” “Have” a consciousness , nor you are “your consciousness”! In reality “You ARE” Consciousness…not that you are “Your Consciousness”! Consciousness is “nobody's”…Consciousness just IS. It is being itself… The only thing is that, at the current stage you consider yourself to be the individual..the perciever, feeler and thinker….a body, mind and an intellect! To such a state Upanishads refer to as “Vimudh Atma” …identifying yourself with a limited being out of ignorance. But your true nature is Existence- Consciousness-Bliss! Just deny everything that you are not…and what you really are will shine on its own ( right now too it is shining, but the different layers of identity cover the reality)

Scientifically and philosophically speaking I honestly don’t believe the verb “TO HAVE” (something) even exists, or makes any sense. “To have” something is, to me, an illusion created by the human egocentric mind. Like “I have a son”… “I have a liver”… “I have cancer”… We used to, traditionally, believe we were body AND consciousness (or body and mind, body and “soul”…). However, modern Physics shows us, more and more, that OBJECTS, bodies, matter, seem to only “pop up” into material existence when measurements are carried out (in between measurements what we used to understand as “material” seems to exist as a fuzzy superposition of potentialities/possibilities). To me - no doubt - we ARE our consciousness. Or - even more appropriately - we are, simply, consciousness. ;-)

Both unless we are unconscious then we are unconscious with a consciousness that is still trying to maintain our energy efficiency the purpose of life’s consciousness, EGMi teaches us to feel and control the focus of our consciousness so we can control which brain hemisphere we are using. We can choose which type of conscious thought and even subconscious to some degree, I choose left brain logical/positive cognition with little right brain anxious/negative cognition, this maximises my brain energy efficiency which was called goodness 10 000 years ago.

In no case is your consciousness a "thing" that you can "have". It is a process that is a function of the operation of your brain. "Where there is consciousness, there are brains." And, as far as we know, where there are no brains, there is no consciousness. Of course, if you believe that consciousness exists as an independent entity outside your brain, then you will reject what I have said here.

Suppose you wake up to the smell of smoke. That happens because your nonconscious brain is always active and it decided to wake up the whole brain and allow the information about the smoke to take the form of conscious awareness of odor. Given that, I have a hard time seeing only the conscious mind as "me". That said, a person who has lost all conscious function isn't really a person.

No. I am many things -- physically, chemically, socially, psychologically, spiritually. My consciousness enables me to be aware of some of the things I am. But there is certainly more to me than my consciousness. Otherwise, when I was unconscious, I would cease to exist. I don't believe that that is the case.
